questions.question: What is the primary purpose of incorporating nickel bis(dicarbollide) into the NU-1000 framework?
questions.answer: The primary purpose of incorporating nickel bis(dicarbollide) into the NU-1000 framework is to create an electrically conductive MOF with mesoporosity by introducing electron-deficient moieties that can serve as acceptors to engender donor–acceptor interactions through the whole framework.

questions.question: How does the presence of NiCB affect the porosity of NU-1000 after its installation?
questions.answer: The presence of NiCB decreases the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of NU-1000 from 2215 m2/g to 1260 m2/g, but the resulting NiCB@NU-1000 still exhibits mesoporosity.

questions.question: What method was used to deposit manganese oxide in both NU-1000 and NiCB@NU-1000, and what was the impact on their BET surface area?
questions.answer: Manganese oxide was deposited in both NU-1000 and NiCB@NU-1000 using atomic layer deposition in MOFs (AIM). This process resulted in a decrease in the BET surface area of NU-1000 from 2215 m2/g to 790 m2/g for Mn-AIM-NU-1000, and from 1260 m2/g to 695 m2/g for Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000.

questions.question: What experimental technique was used to confirm the installation of NiCB in the NU-1000 framework and determine its occupancy?
questions.answer: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was used to confirm the installation of NiCB in the NU-1000 framework and determine its occupancy, which was found to be 100% for Ni sites, corresponding to 0.667 NiCB on each Zr6 node.

questions.question: What was the observed effect on the electrical conductivity of NU-1000 after the incorporation of NiCB?
questions.answer: The incorporation of NiCB into NU-1000 resulted in a remarkable increase in electrical conductivity, with NiCB@NU-1000 achieving an electrical conductivity of 2.7 × 10−7 S/cm.

questions.question: How does the electrochemically addressable fraction of manganese oxide in Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000 compare to that in Mn-AIM-NU-1000?
questions.answer: In the Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000 thin film, 16% of the Mn sites are electrochemically addressable, which is significantly higher than the 1.4% electrochemically addressable Mn sites in the Mn-AIM-NU-1000 thin film.

questions.question: What was the method used to estimate the loading of manganese oxide in the MOF thin films, and what were the results?
questions.answer: The loading of manganese oxide in the MOF thin films was estimated by digesting the spin-coated thin film and measuring the UV-vis spectrum of the obtained solution. The loadings of manganese were 1.2 × 10−7 mol/cm2 for Mn-AIM-NU-1000 and 1.6 × 10−7 mol/cm2 for Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000.

questions.question: True or False: The installation of NiCB in NU-1000 leads to a decrease in mesoporosity.
questions.answer: False. While the BET surface area decreases after the installation of NiCB, the resulting NiCB@NU-1000 still exhibits mesoporosity.

questions.question: True or False: The specific capacitance of manganese oxide in Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000 is more than 10 times higher than that in Mn-AIM-NU-1000.
questions.answer: True. The specific capacitance of manganese oxide in Mn-AIM-NiCB@NU-1000 reaches 276 F/gMnO2, which is more than 10 times higher than that in Mn-AIM-NU-1000 (21 F/gMnO2).

questions.question: True or False: The electrical conductivity of NiCB@NU-1000 is measured to be higher than that of pristine NU-1000.
questions.answer: True. The electrical conductivity of NiCB@NU-1000 is measured to be 2.7 × 10−7 S/cm, indicating an increase in conductivity compared to pristine NU-1000.
